cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Su` ez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos July 20 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos July 20 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1907.

div.head: EXPERIMENTS ON HUMAN BEINGS.
div.p: Some noteworthy evidence, of « rather special kind, was given before the Royal Com- mission on Vivisection by Mr. G. H. Barford, M.B” says the “Yorkshire Poser.”

“Appearing nominally as a representative of the World League of Opponents of Vivisection, Mr. Burfurd confessed that be knew very little about the League or its opinions. He came forward at the request of a friend who is a member, but he himself belongs to no anti- vivisectional: body, and, his object was to express the views of medical men Practising bomampathy in Great Britain and America He believes, however, that the League agrees

"'The homoeopathic method' of investigating the remedial value of drugs is to try them on healthy human beings—healthy in order that the vitiating result of sickness may be eli- minated, baman beeause the major part of s i bomen beings, conscious because the subjective and mental! conditions unattainsble on experiments on animals may be added to the Gudings. The ‘experimenters’ — always voluntary — are in many instances medical men and women. The drag for investigation is takeu first in very small doses, then in larger and repeated doses, the experiment covering sometimes « long period. A great number of such experiments have been made... .

“Mr. Burford admitted that osefal know. ledge has been obtained by experiments on animals, but maintained as regards drogs that the knowledge would be b-tter and- more com- pletely ubtained by the other method ‘A man kuows exactly what are the nécessary limitations when he operates on the haman body. He bas some preliminary knowledge to tell hiai whether his proposed experiment is a fiat defiance of what nature can bear or not. If he was simp y skilled in experimenting on animals he would not koow the exact tax he proposed to levy on the human economy. . . . When you have dea't with animals syou have to deal afterwards with human beings, and thus you have to deal with different tisgues. It is better to go to the human being at once.’

‘When asked for « practical proposal for the amendment of the law, Mr. Burford said he main suggestion he would make was that experimeuts with regard to the remedial action of drugs should in the first instance be carried out on healthy boman beings, and that any point left undecided in the experiments on buman beings might then be considered pos- sibly (I say possibly) as @ fit and proper sub- ject fur experimentation on animals.’

Sir Mackenzie Chalmers asked whether he would have it enacted that a licence should not be granted for an experiment vpon an animal antil a corresponding experiment bad been made on a healthy human being He replied that he would leave discretion to the inspector, aud thatthe Home Office should be required to give specific reasons in each case why the prior investigation on a human being was not adopted.

“This did not seem to strike the Cotmmis- sioners as avery practical proposal, but Mr. Burford said he thought it would be found that in the interest of science a sufficient sup- ply of healthy haman beings would be forth- oouming. Whatever may be said of Mr. Bartotd’s views, they are at least more helpfol than some satirical suggestions made by the Rev. J Page Hopps, in a pamphlet sent to the Commissioners, that experiments should be made on criminals apd intending suitides, instead of on animals—snggestions which were justly characterised by Lord Justice PiéteherMoulton, in his evidence, as ‘loathsome levity.’ ”

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH CO. LTD.
div.p: AVERAGE TIME occupied in transmission of Egyptian telegrams from England to Alexandria on Tuesday, 11th July, 1905.
OUTWARDS.
Between the hours of 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. (Cairo time)
The Luxor Season.

The Laxor Winter Palace Hotel opened its doors for the season yesterday. There are al- ready a good o-mber of people announced acd there is every reason to believe that we shall bave a good tourist season this year. The weather at present in Laxor is beautiful.
The Cairo Season. 7

‘Lhe band ..f the Scotish Borderers played on the terrace of Shepbeard’s Hotel on Saturday afternoon, this being the first terrace concert of the season. A sma!l orchestra has been engaged by the Hotel and will play all the evening during the month of November, until the ar rivalvof the regular band frum Europe.
King Emmanuel's Birthday.

To-day being the 88th anniversary of the birthday of King Victor Emmanuel figs were floated above all the Consulates of Alex- andria and the large houses of the town. The reception held by Marquis di Soragna was attended by the Consular Corps and the élite of the Alexandria Italian community.
Porte and Lights.

On Saturday next the Crimi:al Court of Alexandria will hear the cases brought by the Ports and Lighthouses Administrations against certain of their ewployé¢s and officials accused of bribery and corruption. , Socrates Bey Spiro, against whom ao important charge is made, remains in Europe, but we uaderst nd that be will be tried tm absent-a.
The ‘Sphinx”

Our Cairo contemporary the “Sphinx” hopes to igsue its first number of the season at the ~ @d of the current month. Intending adver- tisers are asked to book space nut later than the 20th, as there is a large demand and disap- pointment may otherwise result. Applications should be addressed to the Manager, Khedivial Buildings, Sharia Bo: lac, Cairo.
Cairo Scientific Society

A Meeting of the Society will be held at the School of Medicine, Kasr el Ainy, at 430 o'clock on Thursday next, the 14th November, when the following papers will be read : Dr. G Elliot Smith ras. “Some N. tes on Mummies.” Dr. W. A. Schmidt. “The prepara- tion of muscleproteid antisera and their u-e in differentiating meats aud meat products in thé practice ot hygiene.”
A Stabbing Affray.

A stabbing affray occurredin the Sharia Clot Bey on Fridav night es the result of an alleged inesalt. It appears that a Greek was sitting at « café, and an Italian in pa-sing stambled over the former’sout-stretched fuot. The! talian refus- ing to believe that the action was not inten- tional. Words ensued which led to the Italian stabbing the Greek with bis knife. The injaries are reported to be only slight.
Alhambra Theatre

“La Signora dalle Camelie” given l»st night at this theatre was a great success for the Italian Dramatic Company. Gemma Caimmi. is well-known and little need to be said as to her dramatic quality Sufficient t» say that she displayed in an extraordinary manver the part of Margherita By her quiet, but most effect. ive acting the peculiarly nervous, hysterical side of the p-rt of Margherita, Siynora Caimmi gave the piece great dramatic significance and brought out the fu | mraning of Dumas. Signor Berti was well appreciated in the part of Armando.
Belle vue Terrace.

The Belle Vue Terrace was last evening the scene of an entertainment rather unique and certainly interesting. This consisted of an “International ladies-wrestling watch” and the way in which some seven members of the “weaker” sex acquitted them-elves proved a great surpride to many of the specrators pre sent, mingled perhaps with a little jealousy. The other items on the programme were Mr Lam), a ventriloquist, Mr. Kikuda a Japanese juguler and Mile Eulalia, a slack wire walker, each performance being goed in its way. The Bohemian orchestra under the direction of Karl Koffmann c mtribs ted some well chosen selections during the evening.
The Savoy Palace.

The Savoy Palace Hotel of Alexandria js fast establishing for itself a reputation equiva. lent to the moat select hotels of Cairo. In the Savoy, indeed, we have an hotel which ca vie with any, and we are sure that under the abie management of Mr. George Brey, whose popularity among hotel frequenters is great, success is guaranteed. Its cuisine is of the highest order, it is fitted up in a most lnxu- rious manner, unknown in Alexandria prior to the opening of the Savoy, and such are its general merits, that it receives the most no table members: of the many cominunities of Eyypt visiting or residing in Alexandria. The visitors tu the hotel during the past week, and many of whom are at present residing there, ‘include Mr. P. W. Machel!, Mr. Harvey, Count and Co ntess Wachtmeister, Moheb Paxha, Mr. Alexander Powell, Mr. and Mrs Walter FP Sarjeait, Mr. Eustratiadis, Mr. Speaker, M. Buubdry, Mr. and Mrs Beyerlé, Mr. Gibbs, Mr., Mrs and Miss Nicholidis, Mr. Rolin, Mr. de Luc, Abdel Kabr Bey, Mr. Gorran, Miss Viedimir, ‘ r. Teher, Mr. Moneri, Mr. Dima- ropoulo, Me Marrandis, Mr. Tilche, Mr. Pis cher, Mrs. Ruger, Mr. Matzaros, Mr. Hollw-an, and Mr. and Mrs. Talek. Tho-e who have reserved apartments and rooms and are ex: pected to arrive shortly include Viscount and Viscountess Finaree, Mr. and Mrs. Schmidt, Messts. A and D. Proost, Mr. and Mrs. Hoghapfel, aod Mr. and Mre. A. O. Millet.
